Award.AwardTitle: Scientific Software Innovation Institute for Computational Chemistry and Materials Modeling (S2I2C2M2) Software Summer School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The (SICM)2 project held an inaugural Software Summer School at Virginia Tech in July 2013. The school involved 26 graduate students (including eight women) from 18 different institutions working with seven instructors and four graduate assistants. The reviews from the students were overwhelmingly positive, and numerous other students have made inquiries regarding future schools. Recognizing the value of this to the students, the research productivity of themselves and their groups, and the huge value for community building, the (SICM)2 project collaboration is holding a second Software Summer School, in this case at Stony Brook.

The Software Summer School promotes community building and broadening participation of groups and individuals nationwide. It takes primarily 1st/2nd year graduate students with some very basic skills in programming and puts them on a trajectory to becoming skilled and professional developers of scientific software who are aware of basic software engineering practices and skills, and also aware of foundational concepts and techniques in HPC. Peer-to-peer engagement is perhaps even more important: students build confidence in themselves by networking with their peers and realizing they are all in the same boat; career-long relationships can form in such events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided over 50% of the support for two summer schools in 2014 and 2015 for graduate students in computational chemistry, materials and biophysics. A major aspect of our original conceptualization project for a Sustainable Software Innovation Institute for Computational Chemistry and Materials Modeling ((SICM)2, http://s2i2.org) was a Software Summer School, which we held on the Virginia Tech campus in July 2013. This first school involved 26 graduate students (including eight women) from 18 different institutions working with seven instructors and four graduate assistants. The reviews from the students were overwhelmingly positive, and numerous other students made inquiries regarding future schools. 

Taught by professional software engineers, active university researchers, staff from Department of Energy National Laboratories and high-tech companies, the 9 day curricula introduced and developed skills and awareness in all aspects of research software development spanning from basic software engineering skills to high-performance programming using distributed memory clusters or graphical processing units. Extensive hands on experience included multiple projects (that spanned classical and and quantum simulation of chemistry and materials), and provided the opportunity for students to work on their own codes and gain advice from the expert instructors and teaching assistants. The summer school in July 2014 at SBU (http://www.iacs.stonybrook.edu/event/workshops/software-development-summer-school-for-computational-chemistry-and-materials) included 34 students (including 8 women and 5 minority) from 14 institutions and departments including chemistry, biophysics, materials sciences and engineering, geosciences, and applied math. The summer school in June 2015 at Virginia Tech (http://s2i2.org/school_2015/) included 43 students (including 11 women and 2 minority).

Intellectual benefits include increasing the research productivity of the students and their groups. These primarily 1st/2nd year graduate students (with some assumed very basic skills in programming) were put on a trajectory to becoming skilled and professional developers of scientific software who are aware of basic software engineering practices and skills, and also aware of foundational concepts and techniques in HPC.

 Broader impacts included helping to establish a more modern and rigorous community wide approach to computation and software engineering. Through peer-to-peer engagement during the summer school, the students (from diverse backgrounds, institutions and disciplines) built confidence in themselves by networking with their peers and realizing they are all in the same boat – from past such events we have seen career-long relationships form. Communication across disciplinary boundaries was also perceived as valuable, with, for instance, students in biophysics being exposed to the techniques and algorithms of quantum chemistry and vice versa.
